Mindsets: Facilitate a discussion on what mindsets we should have going into the program. Write everyone's answer on the board and see where people are at. At the end, put these points up on the boards and say that in design thinking, there are a few additional mindsets that are really important to have. Point out if they have already said any of them. We operate from these mindsets:
Focus on human values: Design thinking is human centered design. We look to understand the needs and emotions of people in order to design solutions for them. Empathy for the people you are designing for and feedback from theseusers is fundamental to good design
Show don’t tell: Wherever you can, show people what you are doing, don’t explain it to them. You learn more from listening and observing real reactions, than having people respond to your talking. This is essential when we get to prototyping. Communicate your vision in an impactful and meaningful way by creating experiences, using illustrative visuals, and telling good stories.
Embrace experimentation: Don’t be afraid to try things. It is ok to fail, in fact, it can be good! The more you experiment and allow yourself to consider different options, the more you will learn and you will get better. Prototyping is not simply a way to validate your idea; it is an integral part of your innovation process. We build to think and learn. 
Be mindful of the process: Know where you are in the design process, what methods to use in that stage, and what your goals are. It is a process for a reason, don’t skip a step, but don’t be afraid to go back if you need more research or to reframe the problem to find better solutions!
Bias towards action: Design thinking is very hands on and action oriented. There will not be a lot of time sitting and learning, we want you to experience everything by doing! Design thinking is a misnomer; it is more about doing that thinking. Bias toward doing and making over thinking and meeting.
Radical collaboration: In order to get a diversity of ideas and solutions, you have to collaborate. In this room there are so many people with different backgrounds and experiences. Use each other to brainstorm and develop your businesses. Later on, you will even collaborate with your customers or anyone else who would interact with your product/service. Bring together innovators with varied backgrounds and viewpoints. Enable breakthrough insights and solutions to emerge from the diversity.
Craft clarity: Things are going to get messy. That is normal, take care to reframe the problem to make it clear. Produce a coherent vision out of messy problems. Frame it in a way to inspire others and to fuel ideation.



USER RESEARCH
5 minutes: Discussion

Empathizing is the first step we will look at in the Design Thinking process. We will empathize with our users through user research. It is the phase where you learn about your customers behaviors, needs, pains, and gains. 
Ask: Why is the user research phase of Design Thinking so important?
User research helps us to understand how people go about performing tasks and achieving goals that are important to them. 
It gives us context and perspective and puts us in a position to respond with useful, simplified, and productive design solutions. 
User research focuses on understanding user expectations, behaviors, needs, and motivations through methodical, investigative approaches. 
It helps us identify unarticulated needs and to fill in any gaps in our knowledge about our users, context of use, challenges, and opportunities. 
It also helps us to align our product and business strategy with the core needs and goals of our users.
Insights are then used to ensure that all product design decisions do benefit the user.

3 minutes: Lecture

Your research plan: Welcome back from your break. I hope you are feeling re-energized! So, as we said before, we all have an idea of who our customers are and what they want, but really, these are just assumptions. We might be right on some things, but we probably don’t have the whole picture. That’s why it is so important to create a research plan. To help us fill these gaps and give us more insights on what our customers need!

How will we do this? Through three research methodologies: Do, Look, and Listen.

Do is all about experiential learning. Putting yourself in the shoes of your customers.

Look is learning through observation. Trying to see the behaviors of your customers to pinpoint needs and opportunities.

Listen is where we talk to our customers through user interviews. Here we hear from them and try to get to the root of their problems and really understand their behaviors and emotions.

20 minutes: Lecture + activity

DO is all about experiencing what your customers experience. In order to understand the pains of your customers, you have to go through the process yourself. For the DO, tell the story of one of IDEO's engineers:
IDEO is one of the leading companies in product development focusing on design thinking methodology. IDEO was working on creating a new design for a stove in a third world country.  They wanted to design a solution for women to make cooking easier for them. So what did they do? They went to the country and used the stove. They experienced how people cooked every day and got to feel how those women felt using that stove. The lesson in this story is that even if you are an expert, you have to go through the same experience of your users to feel their challenges!

15 minutes: Activity - Immerse (DO)
Have participants partner up
Give each pair a task: 
Go into the bathroom and wash your hands, 
Walk around the space, get a book, and put it on the table in the kitchen, 
Make a cup of tea
Do a lap around the space
Get a piece of paper and write directions to the bathroom
You can do anything, be creative!

One participant will close their eyes and try to complete the task, while their partner guides them and makes sure they don’t run into things or hurt themselves
Then switch so that both people go through the process

DEBRIEF: How was that experience? What did it make you learn? How do you think it would be to be blind in a space like this? 
Now think, if you were to design a product for someone who was blind, what are some things you would include? Think about what helped you accomplish the task. Was it useful to hold onto things? Were sounds helpful? Did you like it when someone was in front of you? What were things that frustrated you while you were “blind“, how could that be fixed?
LESSON: It is important to walk in your customers shoes, especially if you are developing a product for them. To see life from their perspective will allow you to truly understand them and their needs


What are they doing? 
How are they doing it?
Why do you think they are doing that?
LOOK
3 minutes: Lecture

Another form of research is observation. You can learn so much by just observing people in their natural routine. While you are watching, take note of a few things:
What are they doing? What are their actual behaviors? List them step by step. Be detail oriented.
How are they doing it? Are they doing something a little odd that needs further explanation? Is it easy for them? Difficult?
Why do you think they are doing that?  What are they trying to accomplish? What is the end goal? 


10 minutes: Activity

Observe (LOOK): What is this a picture of? What do you see?
Spend 5-10 minutes getting thoughts from people. Take the time to build up a story about this person.
Write everyone's thoughts on the board
Remember to touch on the previous slides questions (what, how, why)
What do you see versus what do you think based on what you see?

LESSON: You can learn so much from just looking, taking a step back and trying to figure out what you’re seeing, what you can learn from watching. Keep in mind that you can only learn some things. You can see their actual behaviors. You can observe body language and make assumptions about WHY they are doing it that way. If you can, get some clarification and speak to the person to understand why they did it in that way. 

Ask for stories
Talk about emotions
Ask why?
LISTEN
3 minutes: Lecture

The last research method we are going to cover is the User Interview. In a user interview, you spend 2-30 minutes to speak with customers to hear from them about their experiences. If you take the time to speak to customers, they will tell you everything you would ever need to know about how to make a great product for them. They will tell you what they like and don’t like, the challenges they have with existing solutions and even more! You just have to listen! 



“Tell me about the last time you…”
“What was the best/ worse...”
“Why is that?”
“Can you tell me more?”
LISTEN
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Be careful how you phrase questions. It is important that you don’t lead your customers into saying what you want to hear. By doing this, your interview data will be useless. To give you some example of bad interview questions:
Do you like my idea? People tend to be nice, chances are nobody would want you to feel bad and tell you that you have a bad idea. By asking this, you invite people to say “yes, I like your idea” even though it might not be true. 
Would you buy this product? This is another question that is tricky and usually provides you with false information. Again many people would be tempted to say “yes” or “probably” to this question. The best way to test if people are willing to buy a product is to see if they actually take out their wallet and try. 
Do you have trouble with _____? By posing challenges for them, you are putting words in their mouth. Maybe they do have trouble with that, but you want to hear it from them. Maybe they are facing the challenge differently than you are. Allow them to share their thoughts on their own. Don’t tell or suggest to people how they feel or behave. 
Can you tell me how you normally …..  This question is ALMOST good; however, it is too general. You don’t get any real information. If you ask for generalities (‘what is your normal evening like?’) then you’ll get a false picture, it will be their ‘idealized’ evening. You need to ask a question that allows people to give you a specific story that has real emotions.

So what are good questions to ask? The questions ask for stories, evoke emotions, and go deeper into their actual behaviors. 
“Tell me about the last time you…”  By asking this question, you are able to get very specific information. They will have details about what they liked and didnt like, there might be a timeline, etc... You will get very rich information with this question. 
“What was the best/ worse...” By asking these questions, you are learning more about what the person likes and doesn’t. As you develop your product, it is important to know what your customers care about and what their problems are.
“Why is that?” and “Can you tell me more?” These questions are great for going deeper. If your interviewee says something surprising or interesting, you should want to know more about it. Don’t assume anything, ask them about their thoughts. 
Ask why 5 times – keep asking why so that you get to the deeper meaning and emotion behind decisions. Humans make decisions based on emotion, it’s important for you to understand why your users/ customers make their decisions



INTERVIEW
Introduce yourself
Introduce project
Build rapport
Evoke stories
Explore emotions
Question statements
Thank you & wrap up
Time
5-10 minutes: Lecture + example

Explain all the steps that go into an interview. Here are some tips on what to ask in the beginning, in the middle, and at the end of a user interview:

Beginning: In the beginning of the interview, you should ask opening questions to set people at ease and build rapport. You should not ask about sensitive topics. Instead, focus on setting the stage and bringing your interviewees on board so they’re comfortable enough to be, and remain, open with you. What you do at this stage can include the following:
Telling participants what topics will be covered
Telling participants how their data will be used
Asking innocuous questions such as what their role is in their organization
Asking concrete questions that are easy to answer

Middle: In the middle of the interview, you’re hitting high gear. Having established a direct channel with your interviewees (the users), you move on and ask the bulk of your questions, but maybe not in the order you had originally planned. Remember to:
Keep the flow of the conversation as natural as possible, but cover the topics you want to cover.
Pick up on what participants have said earlier and get full replies to questions they have only partially answered.
Steer participants back on track if they go too far off topic.
Show that you have been listening.
Go deeper where necessary

End: At the end of the interview, you wrap up in a way that makes participants feel as though they have said what they wanted to say and that their answers are valuable. By this point, you will have managed to tie up any loose ends on matters that had not been clear before, and both you and they should be satisfied that the interview has brought all the issues out into the open. Things you should do include:
Asking if there is anything participants would like to add.
Telling your participants what you are going to do with their data and what the value is for them.
Thanking them for taking the time to help with your research. Above all, remember to conduct a pilot study before you start approaching real-life participants and tackling ‘organic’ interview settings. Also, always be sensitive to the fact that people are different and need different things!

5 minutes: Example
Have 2 trainers go through a User Interview. Show a good user interview and a bad one. 


EMPATHY MAP
8 minutes: Brainstorm

So after your interview, you should reflect on and reorganize your information. We will do this through an empathy map. 
After you give the explanation of the empathy map, fill it in for the practice interview you just had in front of the group (with the trainers). Have it be a conversation and write out the answers as a group on the white board. As you discuss together, highlight some information about each quadrant (no need to explain each point in detail!)

The Says quadrant contains what the user says out loud in an interview or some other usability study. Ideally, it contains verbatim and direct quotes from research.
“I love Asiacell because I never have a bad experience.”
“I want something reliable.”
“I don’t understand what to do from here.”
The Thinks quadrant captures what the user is thinking throughout the experience. Ask yourself (from the qualitative research gathered): what occupies the user’s thoughts? What matters to the user? Pay special attention to what users think, but may not be willing to vocalize. Try to understand why they are reluctant to share — are they unsure, self-conscious, polite, or afraid to tell others something?
“This is really annoying.”
“Am I dumb for not understanding this?”
The Does quadrant encloses the actions the user takes. From the research, what does the user physically do? How does the user go about doing it?
Refreshes page several times.
Shops around to compare prices.
The Feels quadrant is the user’s emotional state, often represented as an adjective plus a short sentence for context. Ask yourself: what worries the user? What does the user get excited about? How does the user feel about the experience?
Impatient: pages load too slowly
Confused: too many contradictory prices
Worried: they are doing something wrong

You might encounter inconsistencies — for example, seemingly positive actions but negative quotes or emotions coming from the same user.  This is when empathy maps become treasure maps that can uncover nuggets of understanding about our user. It is our job as UX professionals to investigate the cause of the conflict and resolve it.

Some of these quadrants may seem ambiguous or overlapping — for example, it may be difficult to distinguish between Thinks and Feels. Do not focus too much on being precise: if an item may fit into multiple quadrants, just pick one. The 4 quadrants exist only to push our knowledge about users and to ensure we don’t leave out any important dimension. (If you don’t have anything to put into a certain quadrant, it’s a strong signal that you need more user research before proceeding in the design process.)

**This is important to do together because we consistently have trouble with the entrepreneurs not understanding how to use the empathy map.

Interview Your Users (LISTEN)
5 minutes: prepare questions

10 minutes: 2 rounds of interviews (5 minutes each)
Each person is matched with a partner

Ask them to plot results on the empathy map right after the interview. This is a great way to re-think the interview and reflect.




EXTREME USER
5 minutes: Lecture

When conducting user interviews, make sure to include extreme users. Who are the people who use this product every day? 
For example, if you are making a new cleat, you definitely want to talk to people who play sports (kids, parents who buy them, university students, etc…), but you would probably want to talk to people who LIVE in cleats too. Take professional athletes for example, they know every part of their shoes because they wear them for hours every day. They know about what they love and hate about them. 
Let’s take another example. If we were designing a new type of seat in a car, who would the extreme user be? --- allow them to answer. Taxi drivers live in their cars. All day long they are sitting in the seats and probably know really specific details of what makes them comfortable or not. They might even share ideas on how it could be better.
While creating your user research plan, make sure to include extreme users!
You will want to include at least 1-2 extreme users into your research plan.

------------------------------------
Notes about Extreme Users to help facilitate discussion, no need to explain them all:

When considering the user's needs in design, it’s very easy for a designer to fall into the trap of designing for the first, average user they can think of. 
Only by understanding the viewpoints of a full range of people is it possible to avoid the pitfall of designing for yourself. 
Through speaking to the extreme users and identifying their amplified needs, it can help pull out more meaningful insights and thus gives the potential to push ideas in different directions that you wouldn’t have previously explored. 
This group of users can help spark creativity by introducing you to hacks and use cases you wouldn’t have imagined. 
In the hope of trying to please the mainstream, which is still a very diverse group, it’s all too easy to end up designing something generic and easy to replicate.
An idea that suits an extreme user is more likely to please the mainstream users too. 
By focusing on the extremes, you can find the highest priority issues. Most commonly, the high priority issue is what motivates people to buy this thing, and what is keeping them from buying this thing?
Extreme user's are most in-tune with their needs, emotions and behaviors when using a product or service and can, therefore, articulate needs/challenges better. 

Designing from your own experiences. You are not the user.
Asking the user to design for you.
Asking the user to respond to your idea.
USER RESEARCH IS NOT:
3 minutes: Remember!

Designing from your own experiences. You are not the user. 
Remember you want to make sure they are talking, not you!
Don’t assume things, allow them to share their own experiences

Asking the user to design for you
Don’t ask your interviewer what they think the solution is
Don’t have them list features
YOU are the designer! You need to gather information from people to create the solution that will best fit their needs. By asking others to design for you, you stunt your creativity and can come up with generic solutions.

Asking the user to respond to your idea
Avoid asking the user if they like your idea. Any person will just say “yes, I like it” or “yes, I will use/buy this”
In general, people are polite, so you shouldn’t trust what they say in that way. Make sure the questions are framed in a way where you are just focusing on the challenges they are facing and learning about how they are currently dealing with them.
You should NOT give an explanation of your idea in a user interview.
